body:
Add wrapper for bpf_link__open, bpf_link__pin_path and bpf_link__detach.

Fixes #199

add wrapper around `bpf_program__insn_cnt`


Fixes #200

Replace deprecated btf__get_raw_data with btf__raw_data.

Add support for BTF_KIND_FLOAT and BTF_KIND_DECL_TAG.

Closes #172.

title: libbpf-rs: Add new BPF map type definitions
body: Signed-off-by: Hengqi Chen <chenhengqi@outlook.com>

title: libbpf-rs: Omit get_ prefix for getters
body:
Let's follow the Rust ([0]) and libbpf ([1]) naming conventions,
omit the get_ prefix for getters.

  [0]: https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0344-conventions-galore.md#gettersetter-apis
  [1]: https://github.com/libbpf/libbpf/wiki/Libbpf:-the-road-to-v1.0

Signed-off-by: Hengqi Chen <chenhengqi@outlook.com>

title: libbpf-rs: Add set_autoload/set_attach_target to OpenProgram
body:
Add bpf_program__set_autoload / bpf_program__set_attach_target equivalent API to libbpf-rs.

Closes #175 and #176.

Signed-off-by: Hengqi Chen <chenhengqi@outlook.com>

title: docs: update README to use latest crate versions
body: Quick docs update to use the latest dependency versions.

body:
Ubuntu 20.04 has recently added BTF into it's kernel
BTF tests can now be run

Signed-off-by: Michael Mullin <mimullin@blackberry.com>

title: Cargo.toml updates
body:
Update packages to latest versions.

Get the repository ready for a cargo audit (query -> bpf_query)

title: perf_buffer: Add epoll_fd, consume, consume_buffer, ... wrappers
body:
This patch adds epoll_fd, consume, consume_buffer, buffer_cnt, and
buffer_fd support for perf buffers.

This is part of a larger effort to reach feature-parity with libbpf.

Signed-off-by: Joanne Koong <joannekoong@gmail.com>

title: util: Add parse_ret helper functions
body:
This patch adds helper functions for parsing the return code into its
corresponding Result.

Signed-off-by: Joanne Koong <joannekoong@gmail.com>

title: Replace deprecated libbpf functions
body:
`bpf_map__next` and `bpf_program__next` are deprecated in libbpf in favor of
`bpf_object__next_map` and `bpf_object__next_program`.

This patch replaces our uses of `bpf_map__next` and `bpf_program__next` with
the updated APIs.

Signed-off-by: Joanne Koong <joannekoong@gmail.com>

title: build: Download latest version of Rust before building
body:
Without this action, we otherwise default to using the
ubuntu-latest version of Rust.

Signed-off-by: Joanne Koong <joannekoong@gmail.com>

title: libbpf-rs: Fix clippy error in examples/query
body: Signed-off-by: Joanne Koong <joannekoong@gmail.com>

title: Add reuse_fd function to allow non-pinned BPF maps to be reused
body:
…_fd to allow for non-pinned maps to be used

Signed-off-by: Yadunandan Pillai <ytpillai@pm.me>

title: Minor fixe and addition
body:
* Add get_section_name function for Program
* Fix pages method for PerfBuffer

title: libbpf-cargo: __unnamed_ is unnecessary as a field prefix
body:
Rust can have a field name be the same as the type.  __unnamed_ is
not necessary for unnamed unions, and harms readability

Signed-off-by: Michael Mullin <mimullin@blackberry.com>

title: libbpf-cargo: Make generated object files deterministic by not using a temporary directory for include headers
body:
Clang includes the name of the directory where includes are stored in the `.debug_line` section of
the headers when debug info is enabled. Since the directory was randomly created on each new run,
that meant the object file varied randomly each time it was created.

This changes the directory name to be consistently in a subdirectory of `target/` instead.

Fixes https://github.com/libbpf/libbpf-rs/issues/163. Closes https://github.com/libbpf/libbpf-rs/pull/169.

Signed-off-by: Joshua Nelson <jnelson@cloudflare.com>

title: libbpf-cargo: Cannot generate unnamed unions
body:
An unnamed union in C cannot be generated to rust code as rust demands
names on it's variables.

Solution: Give the union a name of __unnamed_X where X is the
declaration of the union.

Signed-off-by: Michael Mullin <mimullin@blackberry.com>

NOTE: The usage of __unnamed_ and __anon_ requires the consumer-programmer of the skeleton have intimate knowledge of the generated skeleton.   Please see the usage of __unnamed _anon_1 and __unnamed_anon_4 in the test code.  IMHO this is exceptionally confusing to the users of libbpf-cargo.
We need to figure out the best way to make this easier for consumers; but this code will at least stop compile breaking unnamed union code.

title: Fix formatting for libbpf-cargo/src/test.rs
body: No functional changes.

title: Allow having package.metadata sections that aren't for libbpf
body:
This allows having sections of the following form in Cargo.toml:
```
[package.metadata.deb]
    # ...
```

Previously, they would give a hard error:

```
$ cargo libbpf make
Compiling BPF objects
Error: Failed to compile BPF objects

Caused by:
    Failed to process package=bpf-graceful-restart, error=unknown variant `deb`, expected `libbpf`
```

Serde by default requires all enum variants to be known ahead of time;
this works by changing the deserialized type to a struct instead.

Signed-off-by: Joshua Nelson <jnelson@cloudflare.com>

Fixes https://github.com/libbpf/libbpf-rs/issues/164.

title: Implement Clippy recommendations on examples and libbpf-rs
body: This change enables a clean clippy check over the entire libbpf-rs project assuming clippy defaults (+branches_sharing_code linter).  IMHO clippy enhances the code quality of the project.

title: libbpf-cargo: Implement cargo clippy recommendations
body:
libbpf-cargo does not have a clean pass of 'cargo clippy'.

Solution: Implement changes recommended by running cargo clippy over
libbpf-cargo source files

Signed-off-by: Michael Mullin <mimullin@blackberry.com>

NOTE: libbpf-rs has many more clippy recomendations.  I am not comfortable working on that until the unit tests are working as per PR: https://github.com/libbpf/libbpf-rs/pull/158

title: Test Updates for libbpf-rs
body:
There is an error in the test version of runqslower.bpf.c which was addressed in a previous commit to the examples/ code, but not updated in the testing code.

To address this issue
patch 0: build a small infrastructure to easily recompile the bpf objects contained in libbpf-rs/tests/bin.  
patch 1: Then update runqslower in the libbpf-rs/tests/bin/src directory and recompile the bpf object
patch 2: libbpf now has .bss as a map, and the test.rs code must be updated to observe that test.
patch 3: two tests are racing on a pined map. Rename the map to be explicit to the test being run

NOTE: Apologies for replying to comments using the masmullin2000 address.  I was incorrectly logged in to my personal github account while replying.  masmullin2000 and mimullin-bbry are the same person.

title: libbpf-cargo: Skip the output of datasec static variables
body:
In libbpf 6.0+ bpf_printk is using a static const for the ____fmt
variable under certain conditions. This is causing an error when
generating rust code for the rodata.  libbpf-rs should skip generation
of fields for static variables.

Solution: Skip generation of static variables while parsing datasec

Signed-off-by: Michael Mullin <mimullin@blackberry.com>

body:
Fix the issue with:

```
error[E0063]: missing fields `__bindgen_padding_0` and
`__bindgen_padding_1` in initializer of `bpf_object_open_opts`
  -->
  /home/andriin/.cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/libbpf-rs-0.13.0/src/object.rs:62:9
     |
     62 |         libbpf_sys::bpf_object_open_opts {
        |         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ missing
	`__bindgen_padding_0` and `__bindgen_padding_1`
```

This is supposed to be fixed with the libbpf-sys update to 0.5.0-2 ([0]).

Signed-off-by: Andrii Nakryiko <andrii@kernel.org>

title: libbpf-rs: add sk_lookup
body: This PR adds a `attach_sk_lookup` in order to implement [sk_loopup programs](https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/bpf/prog_sk_lookup.html).

title: Emit type declarations for structs in global array variables.
body:
The following code causes `SkeltonBuilder` to emit invalid Rust because it doesn't define `struct foo`:

**src/sample.bpf.c**
```
struct foo {
    int x;
};

const volatile struct foo array[1] = { {0} };
```

**build.rs**
```
use libbpf_cargo::SkeletonBuilder;

fn main() {
    SkeletonBuilder::new("src/sample.bpf.c")
        .debug(true)
        .generate("src/sample_skel.rs")
        .unwrap();
}
```

Build output:
```
$ cargo build
   Compiling libbpf-cargo v0.9.2 (/home/ben/scratch/libbpf-rs/libbpf-cargo)
   Compiling example-broken v0.1.0 (/home/ben/scratch/libbpf-rs/example-broken)
error[E0412]: cannot find type `foo` in this scope
  --> src/sample_skel.rs:65:19
   |
65 |         pub bar: [foo; 1],
   |                   ^^^ not found in this scope

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0412`.
error: could not compile `example-broken` due to previous error
```

title: update to libbpf-sys 0.5.0-2
Add set_print, to send libbpf output to a callback
body: I want to be able to send output from libbpf-rs to the `log` crate and filter it by level, along with all the other chatter my application produces. Right now the best I can do is send it to stderr. This PR adds `set_print`, which allows a user-defined callback to receive libbpf output.

title: libbpf-cargo: fix bpf code build on aarch64
body: set __TARGET_ARCH_arm64.

title: Bump libbpf-rs and libbpf-cargo
Bump libbpf-sys to 0.5.0-1 plus a few more dependencies
body: In preparation for a new below release

title: Capable using libbpf
body:
Hi Guys,
I'm new to a few things - Rust and ebpfs. @anakryiko's your blog posts a good starting point resource when approaching ebpfs from a high level language. I had a few issues with my dev env that @danobi helped with- ty for that. I took the suggestion in the blogposts and partially converted [capable(8)](https://github.com/iovisor/bcc/blob/master/tools/capable.py) to contribute as an example here and possibly contribute more to this repo, if I can. I say partially because:

* [filter_by_containers()](https://github.com/iovisor/bcc/blob/0120770f3cdcd0540861e2f92c4f796fe09c3ff6/src/python/bcc/containers.py#L73) is a cool helper function in bcc. I thought of implementing it myself, coz it seems to be doable. But I thought, it would be better if it was implemented in someway through ``bpf_helpers.h``. I also noticed all libbpf converted tools that had this function used in their bcc versions just decided to ignore it and not implement the ``--cgroupmap`` and 
``--mntnsmap`` options
* [These](https://github.com/iovisor/bcc/blob/0120770f3cdcd0540861e2f92c4f796fe09c3ff6/tools/capable.py#L261) 4 lines of code hide a whole lot of code that is provided by BCC to do stacktrace stuff. I noticed that libbpf-tools that dealt with stack traces used @ethercflow's(your blog posts helped as well) code in ``trace_helpers``. I was wondering why it's not part of libbpf and by extension libbpf-rs, since a lot of the converted tools do use that and bcc provides that. Hence the stacktrace options are a no-op right now
* The blogposts talk about considering using ``raw_tp/fentry/fexit`` instead of ``tracepoint/kprobe/kretprobe``.  Bcc had a few helper functions around detecting the presence of these features. I thought I could use ``LINUX_KERNEL_VERSION >= KERNEL_VERSION(x, y, z)`` to get around this. But then I saw how a few libbpf-tools did it by using ``fentry_exists(name, mod)`` which made me think its not that simple. However, that function is also part of ``trace_helpers`` - not libbpf.  After detection of those features, libbpf lets you disable autoload. But, I don't think thats possible in libbf-rs right now. The disable autoload exists in ``libbpf_sys`` and is exposed through ``libbpf_rs`` - but the ``bpf_program`` is a private member of the generated code and hence can't be passed over. So for now I just have the ``kprobe`` implemented. Till this detection and autoload disabling  is possible, the ``fentry`` version probably stays commented.

Apart from the request to absorb ``trace_helpers``, I thought it would be cool to actually distribute the latest ``vmlinux.h`` within libbpf and libbpf-rs/cargo(I have a feeling rustaceans might oppose this) to be used in development because I just noticed that I have the same ``vmlinux.h`` as the ``runqslower`` example. 

Also, if you noticed bcc capable  has a lot of ``#ifdefs`` in structs that are controlled by user args, probably to reduce struct size if those options aren't used. I know thats not possible as-is with libbpf, any suggestions on how to achieve this in a smart manner? 

All comments, thoughts and code reviews are highly appreciated :)

title: Lookup and update all values for per-cpu maps
body:
A successful lookup of a key in a per-cpu map does not return just one value but one value per CPU. These values written to the buffer aligned to 8 bytes. 

Currently, the `Vec` returned by `lookup` would just contain the first value. In addition, libbpf would write to memory areas outside the allocated buffer. This may cause crashes.

This PR makes `lookup` return a `Vec` with all values and proper alignment when called on per-cpu maps.
